articles.headline: China’s Utilities Cut Energy Production, Defying Beijing
articles.snippet: A dispute spurred by rising coal prices indicates that China’s unique marriage of market competition and government oversight may be starting to fray.
articles.abstract: A dispute spurred by rising coal prices indicates that China’s unique marriage of market competition and government oversight may be starting to fray.
articles.lead_paragraph: YIYANG, China — It is a power struggle that is causing a power shortage — one that has begun to slow China’s mighty economic growth engine.

articles.headline: Chrysler Pays Back Rescue Loan
articles.snippet: The carmaker said it made payments of $5.9 billion to the United States Treasury and $1.7 billion to Export Development Canada in a series of transactions completed Tuesday morning.
articles.abstract: The carmaker said it made payments of $5.9 billion to the United States Treasury and $1.7 billion to Export Development Canada in a series of transactions completed Tuesday morning.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Chrysler paid back on Tuesday $7.6 billion in loans from the American and Canadian governments, paving the way for its Italian partner, Fiat, to increase its control over the Detroit carmaker.

articles.headline: U.S. Suit Sees Manipulation of Oil Trades
articles.snippet: The authorities are suing three companies and two individuals for reportedly manipulating the crude oil market in early 2008.
articles.abstract: The authorities are suing three companies and two individuals for reportedly manipulating the crude oil market in early 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: After oil prices surged past $100 a barrel in 2008, suspicions that traders had manipulated the market led to Congressional hearings and regulatory investigations. But they produced no solid cases in the record run-up in gasoline prices.

articles.headline: Decorum Breaks Down at House Hearing
articles.snippet: A panel chairman accused Elizabeth Warren, who is directing the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, of lying.
articles.abstract: A panel chairman accused Elizabeth Warren, who is directing the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, of lying.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A House committee hearing on Tuesday about the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau disintegrated into heated accusations of lying, with the panel’s chairman accusing Elizabeth Warren of giving misleading testimony at a hearing in March and of making up facts about her agreement to testify this week.

articles.headline: Top Colleges, Largely for the Elite
articles.snippet: The admissions policies of elite colleges don’t matter just to high school seniors; they’re a matter of national interest.
articles.abstract: The admissions policies of elite colleges don’t matter just to high school seniors; they’re a matter of national interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last four presidents of the United States each attended a highly selective college. All nine Supreme Court justices did, too, as did the chief executives of General Electric (Dartmouth), Goldman Sachs (Harvard), Wal-Mart (Georgia Tech), Exxon Mobil (Texas) and Google (Michigan).

articles.headline: Revolutionary Cuba Now Lays Sand Traps for the Bourgeoisie
articles.snippet: Fifty years after Fidel Castro rid Cuba of golf courses, developers say the country’s government has given preliminary approval for four large luxury golf resorts on the island.
articles.abstract: Fifty years after Fidel Castro rid Cuba of golf courses, developers say the country’s government has given preliminary approval for four large luxury golf resorts on the island.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — One of Fidel Castro’s first acts upon taking power was to get rid of Cuba’s golf courses, seeking to stamp out a sport he and other socialist revolutionaries saw as the epitome of bourgeois excess.

articles.headline: Daunting Task for NATO in Libya as Strikes Intensify
articles.snippet: From the start (political orders in Brussels) to the finish (striking targets in Tripoli), there is nothing simple about NATO’s nightly bombing campaign.
articles.abstract: From the start (political orders in Brussels) to the finish (striking targets in Tripoli), there is nothing simple about NATO’s nightly bombing campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: OVER THE MEDITERRANEAN SEA — Just after midnight on Sunday, an allied Mirage 2000 fighter jet prowling the Libyan coastline attacked a Libyan missile patrol boat that military officials said threatened NATO and humanitarian aid vessels in nearby waters.

articles.headline: All That Glitters May Redefine Run by Gingrich
articles.snippet: To the long list of rich-guy foibles that turned into defining campaign moments, let us now add Newt Gingrich’s $500,000 revolving line of credit at Tiffany.
articles.abstract: To the long list of rich-guy foibles that turned into defining campaign moments, let us now add Newt Gingrich’s $500,000 revolving line of credit at Tiffany.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To the long list of rich-guy foibles that turned into defining campaign moments — John Edwards’s $400 haircut, John Kerry’s kite-surfing, John McCain’s inability to remember how many homes he owns — let us now add Newt Gingrich’s $500,000 revolving line of credit at the luxury jeweler Tiffany & Company.

articles.headline: Democrats Put G.O.P. on Spot as Medicare Plan Fails
articles.snippet: The plan advanced by House Republicans to reshape Medicare was defeated, with five Republicans opposing it.
articles.abstract: The plan advanced by House Republicans to reshape Medicare was defeated, with five Republicans opposing it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Less than 24 hours after their surprising victory in the race for a vacant House seat, Democrats forced Senate Republicans on Wednesday to vote yes or no on a bill that would reshape Medicare, signaling their intent to use the issue as a blunt instrument against Republicans through the 2012 election.
